Those who write in support of the Northern Territory legislation use words like `choice' and `control', and it seems to me that one of their greatest fears is that, in the unknown experience of dying, they will not be able to exercise the control over their lives which they presently enjoy.

We live in a high‐tech age—an age of press‐button control over just about all aspects of our daily living, from education, communication, entertainment and learning to cooking and washing, and even turning on the light. Death alone remains uncontrollable, and it is the last unknown frontier. To the rational modern mind, to be able to have control to choose the time of our own deaths appears to be a logical step. But we should not be too ready to be beguiled by technology and rational solutions for our own private fears. The danger is too great, and that danger is not only that this legislation will devalue and undermine the intrinsic value that we place on human life, but the very danger of evolving a death dealing culture through the abuse of this legislation is all too real. Such a culture will eventually undermine the humanity in all of us, thus threatening the foundations of society as we know it.

And when such a culture develops, the legislation which allows for human beings to be dispatched by another as a process of administrative homicide will, like all other legislation, certainly be abused. As a lawyer, I am well aware that legislation is often abused. But the abuse of this legislation is murder. The experience of the Netherlands, which has already been well documented in this House, clearly shows that, in spite of every possible safeguard, in a one‐year period, 55 per cent of deaths by so‐called euthanasia were carried out without the consent of the person so euthanised. In other words, these people were executed. In the United Kingdom, the House of Lords select committee investigating voluntary euthanasia finally rejected it on the grounds that it was impossible to guarantee that it would not be abused, and that the required voluntary aspect could not be ensured.

It is with this very real knowledge that every other law that has ever been written has been abused to a greater or lesser extent that persuades me of the real dangers of this corrosive law and the abuse that will surely follow. A culture of death will evolve and it will be based on sound rational principles, and the deserving will be the independent, the healthy and the productive.

I fear this legislation will engender the formation of a social definition of the quality of life, and, since social definitions generally reflect the imperatives of society, any argument that the legislation would afford the individual a purely personal objective is destroyed. I believe that the individual will have the general social imperative imposed upon him or her rather than exercise any free choice in the matter. Then, of course, the economic rational argument will follow as an example of social imperative.
Father Christopher Toohey, the director of the Sydney archdiocese office, wrote in his letter to me of 2 November this year:

BREAK.PARA: Persons who cannot `fit' the rationalist criterion for living as whole productive autonomous members of our society will be at most risk. Their vulnerability will be compounded by the fact that having imbibed the culture's core attitudes and values of `disposability,' they themselves will feel coercion, even moral obligation—albeit distorted—to relinquish their right to live and to engage another, who will perhaps be motivated by duty, in the process of their termination. If such a culture develops, it will mean that we Australians have abrogated the very heart of our own national sense of self.
I could not put it better than Mr Toohey.
We are really on dangerous ground here. This corrosive legislation threatens us all individually, as a society and as a nation, and there are those amongst us who already express these sentiments.
I refer to the speech of one of our leading identities, the then Governor‐General, Mr Bill Hayden, on 21 June 1995, in which an extreme economic logic found a most disturbing expression. He said:
There is a point when the succeeding generations deserve to be disencumbered of some unproductive burdens.

It seems to me that if you only see the unproductive burden, if we can only define our fellow citizens by their quality of life, if we fail to see the human being within, then we are already very close to the culture of death. From there, where do we go?

We only have to look at nations where there is no respect for human life, no laws, no order, no social or stable relationships. We only have to look at Rwanda and Zaire, and other African nations where ancient tribal brutality is but the most violent physical expression of the absence of any respect for human life.

`Oh no,' you say, `it could never happen here. We are not Rwanda. We are Australia. We are a rich and wealthy nation. We are the lucky country and, anyway, we do not have such historical tribal antagonisms.' True; but the culture of death will evolve just the same, if not in the same manifestation. There will be no blood and bodies in our rivers or on our streets.

In our high‐tech sophistication, we can be assured that subtlety and clinical discretion will prevail. The abuse of this kind of legislation will see that the culture of death will be there all the same. The act of lawful killing will eventually corrode the prohibition against killing that is the foundation of good order in our Australian society. We will all be diminished by the devaluation of human life. None of us are islands. We are all connected in our humanness. But John Donne says it better than I:
Any man's death diminishes me, because I am involved in Mankind; And therefore never send to know for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for thee.
I support the Kevin Andrews bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Draper, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the Kevin Andrews Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. I do so knowing that I especially have a very serious and solemn responsibility, not only to all of the members of the electorate of Makin, but also to every person in Australia. I have, over the past few months, endeavoured to canvass the concerns of as many constituents in my electorate as possible with regard to the Kevin Andrews bill and, surprisingly, the results were roughly fifty‐fifty, rather than the 70 to 80 per cent support for euthanasia that is seen in some surveys.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that this is a territory or states rights issue. The issue we are debating in this instance is the legalisation of euthanasia. Whichever way you want to put it, legalised euthanasia is state sanctioned assistance by a person to cause the death of another, or the state sanctioned killing of another person. The main argument for that premise is to be able to die with dignity and freedom from pain and suffering.

The most important dilemma that arises from the issues relating to the euthanasia debate is: what sort of society do we want for ourselves in 30 or so years time? As I see it, the consequences of decisions we make today will not necessarily be felt immediately, or within a week, months or a few years, but rather within a generational time span.

As well as being a parent to three boys before entering parliament, I had the honour of being a nurse over the past 15 years in the area of aged care, incorporating nursing home, palliative and hostel care. I did not feel that I was wasting my time in caring for our elderly who were in need of nursing care. I felt that I had a valuable contribution to make in assisting our elderly and those with terminal illnesses to live their passing years or months with dignity, comfort and to be as free from pain and suffering as possible.
Some people may share the view of the former Governor‐General, Mr Bill Hayden, who when speaking to the Royal Australian College of Physicians stated:
There is a point when the succeeding generations deserve to be disencumbered of some unproductive burdens.

I would have to say that I have never felt that any of the residents I have nursed were `unproductive burdens'. The residents were not considered by nursing colleagues, the management team, domestic staff, nor the volunteers in my former place of employment to be `unproductive burdens'.

We do live in a pluralist and increasingly secular and hedonistic society, with many individuals holding differing personal points of view, demanding more autonomy and rights to self‐interest, perhaps at the expense of others or regardless of others.

As members of parliament, we have a responsibility and duty to protect and legislate for the vulnerable, the elderly, the disabled and the sick and not to disencumber our society of `unproductive burdens' because they are perceived to be inconvenient, hard work, or of nuisance value. For how far do we go with euthanasia if the Northern Territory laws were allowed to stand 30 years hence?

I would ask the question for a person born in the year 1996, living with a new set of societal mores and a new community value system created by the euthanasia legislation. If that person chose to be a nurse in the area of aged care, would they ever be taught palliative care techniques, respect, care and dignity for those in need of that care? Or would the majority of our new generations of nurses in aged care, 30 years hence, be taught solely the best practice of cleaning and sterilising computer keyboards, explanatory techniques on how best to, and in which position to, press particular buttons and, following that, procedures on how best to dispose of the body for burial or cremation?

Those who support euthanasia may feel that this situation could never occur, and that perhaps I am being unrealistic, but we are all human and human nature means that there can never be 100 per cent safeguards in relation to the abuse of laws governing euthanasia.

As a nurse experienced in the area of aged care, I feel that I can speak with some authority on the possible ramifications of the Northern Territory legislation in relation to ruthless relatives, potential benefactors, unscrupulous providers of aged care and the insidious push for the non‐utilisation of expensive medical resources for those who some in our society would say do not really deserve them nor should have access to them.

BREAK.PARA: However, before I speak on those issues, I would like to discuss the Remmelink report examining voluntary euthanasia in the Netherlands. It was discovered that, out of approximately 25,000 people euthanased, approximately 14,000 of those were euthanased without the consent of either themselves, their family or a person appointed to make those decisions. The situation in the Netherlands has deteriorated to the point of complete disregard for the law, whereby doctors giving evidence were not arguing whether or not they had euthanased, that is, murdered or killed elderly patients without their or their family's consent, but they were arguing about the actual number they had killed—whether it was 600 or 1,000.

It was also found through surveys and anecdotal evidence that elderly people were too frightened to visit their general practitioner in case they were found to be burdensome or too old and that the ultimate treatment for their ailment were recommended—euthanasia.

This is the reality today in the Netherlands. In fact, the argument is now being pushed to include the disabled as well as deformed babies and other so‐called unproductive citizens. Hitler would have been proud, although Hitler and, we thought, his ideals, died a long time ago. The `brave new world' is already here in the Netherlands.

Some of my colleagues on both sides of the argument have stated they have been with a relative, a loved one or, in some cases, a patient who was dying of a terminal illness and that it was hard to witness the pain and suffering they went through. Not only did I look after my own mother, who died of inoperable cancer in 1984 when palliative care was not widely practised, but I have witnessed many deaths while nursing in the area of aged care.

For those who have not experienced the following situation, I will say a few words on ruthless relatives. Whilst I was on evening shift, the dying resident I was caring for was visited by her son‐in‐law's brother and his wife at around 10.30 p.m. The resident was expected to pass away within 24 hours or so. The woman approached me as I was going about my duty and asked would I mind, as this poor lady was going to die at any moment, removing her wedding ring and very valuable antique engagement ring from her fingers because she had not been able to manage it; that when the resident's daughter came to visit the following day she would be able to get the rings and that would not be fair. The visitor really wanted them because `they were really nice and no‐one would miss the rings anyway' because the resident in question had so much money.

My response to the woman's request was to tell her that it was an inappropriate request, that I had no authority to remove any valuables from the room, let alone rings from the dying woman's fingers, and had to ask them to leave, reporting the incident to the duty sister‐in‐charge.

This is just a single example—although in the minority—of how, sadly, some relatives of aging residents attempt to take advantage of and exploit the residents' goodwill, stripping their homes of valuables, furniture and bank accounts in their misguided perceptions of fairness, justice and their rights.

If euthanasia had been legalised some years ago, I have no doubt that I would not have had the opportunity to have met many of the residents I had the pleasure to care for. Their families would have disposed of these so‐called unproductive burdens long ago. At the other end of the scale, there are residents who, because they do require assistance in care, feel as though they are a burden on the nurses, their families and their doctors.

Recent arguments in relation to the euthanasia debate have included the problematic question of residents with dementia. The reality of looking after residents with dementia is that it is a much more difficult and often thankless, emotionally exhausting task. However, surely, as members of parliament, we have the responsibility of fostering and promoting the community values of mutual support and caring and good management of illnesses rather than promoting the concept that human life is disposable because of economic, productive, burdensome or autonomy reasons.

I would also argue that, as a society, we should be working harder to ensure that those with a terminal illness have the necessary support systems and access to palliative care to allow them to live their last moments with dignity and comfort, without pain and suffering. As to the argument for relief of pain and suffering as the main reason for the introduction of the euthanasia bill into the Northern Territory legislation, according to Dr John Zalizberg, `The Northern Territory has no medical oncologist, virtually no radiotherapy services, not a single palliative care specialist, a barely resourced domiciliary palliative care program and not a single hospice.'

I humbly suggest, and commend to all members of parliament, both state and federal, that it would be advantageous to examine the South Australian select committee report on the law and practice relating to death and dying, 1992. I believe that the South Australian Consent to Medical Treatment and Palliative Care Act 1995, is the most practical and sensible act in relation to the questions of death and dying. The act allows for the provision of a living will, the right to refuse extraordinary and cumbersome treatments to prolong life unnecessarily. The emphasis on the intent of the utilisation of pain relieving drugs is most relevant.

Let us not go down the path of the brave new world; rather let us, as parliamentarians, fight for access to effective palliative care and dignity in life. We should aim to remove the pain and suffering of the terminal illness, not remove the patient. I support the Kevin Andrews bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We spend a lot of time in this parliament debating matters such as schools and hospitals, and these are all very important, but this bill is about the essence of what it means to be a human being. It is, in fact, the most important bill currently before the parliament and, like many others, I am disappointed that it is not being debated in the main chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I am against the Northern Territory's euthanasia bill because it does not confer a right to die, it confers a right to kill. It is not about turning off life support machines, it is about the administration of lethal injections. I support a right to die because it is one thing not to keep alive someone who would otherwise be dead but it is an entirely different thing to kill someone who would otherwise be alive.

Under Australian law, no‐one is compelled to live. Attempted suicide is not illegal anywhere in Australia. It is no longer illegal in the Northern Territory, which only repealed its law this year. Suicide is one thing, but killing, even consensual killing, is an entirely different thing again. Medical execution is no more acceptable than judicial execution: allowing someone else to administer a lethal injection is no more acceptable than allowing someone else to administer a fatal revolver shot. The fact that the victim may say that he or she wants it does not make it right, because no‐one is capable of making a sound decision on matters such as this in the grip of paralysing fear or agonising pain.

I am very conscious of Mr Bob Dent's statement when he said that someone kept in his condition and kept living like a dog would be reported to the RSPCA. That is entirely the point—human beings are not dogs. It might be sad, but we do get rid of our problem animals. It is completely unacceptable ever to get rid of people, however many problems they might be causing us.

As I said, the right to die is not the same as the right to kill or be killed. States rights, such as they are, can never be at odds with human rights. Human rights are always more important than state or institutional rights. Human rights are in some sense absolute, whereas institutional rights are more matters of administrative convenience or practical efficiency.

In the course of this debate, a number of speakers have said that they are opposed to euthanasia but they support the Northern Territory's right to make law. That is a version of Voltaire, saying, `I oppose what you do but I defend your right to do it.' If someone has the power to stop something and refuses to exercise it, that person is complicit in the act.

This is not something that this parliament has no power to stop. Let us be very clear about this. This national parliament has the right to stop the Northern Territory's euthanasia program. This is not an area where misguided policy can be tolerated in the cause of social harmony or in the interests of proper give and take.

If a state tried to re‐introduce capital punishment, this parliament, quite rightly and properly, would try to intervene. If a state tried to introduce a system of apartheid, this parliament, very properly, would try to intervene. If a local council tried to introduce confiscatory fines for breaches of trivial ordinances, this parliament or other parliaments would try to intervene.

We do intervene constantly in environmental, industrial and economic matters. These are comparatively small things. If it is right to intervene in those things, surely it is right and proper to intervene in the most important question of all—the question of life and death. If this parliament cannot decide these matters, what is the point of having a national parliament?

I deeply respect my friend and colleague the member for Flinders (Mr Reith). I deeply respect his views on the desirability of the devolution of powers but, with respect to those views, I do not detect any move to hand industrial relations back to the states. `None of my business' is a terrible cop‐out. It is a terrible cop‐out, and it is not something that should ever be heard here in the national parliament.

I have heard lots of people in the course of this debate telling us that euthanasia happens anyway. I think it is important for those people to ask themselves these questions. Is legalising it going to make the practice more or less widespread? Is legalising euthanasia going to make the very old and the very sick feel more or less vulnerable?

I know that the deepest anxiety for the old and the weak is worrying about being a burden. I know it, because every time I see my grandmother, she frets about this very problem. But if euthanasia were to become legal, what additional, self‐generated pressure might these people be under—let alone the pressure from relatives eager for a quick inheritance, let alone the pressure from medical administrators anxious to have another empty hospital bed? Euthanasia, it seems to me, is the ultimate form of economic rationalism—the ultimate statement that everything has its price, even human life.

Consider the case of a comatose patient lying in a hospital bed, with little hope of recovery, every day a burden on his or her family, every day a burden on the taxpayer. Of course it would be easier to give such a person one cheap, final injection, rather than to give him or her an endless series of expensive injections. It would be much easier, but it would not be right because convenience never justifies acts as grave as this.

BREAK.PARA: It is always easier to get rid of our problems rather than to live with them but, in the course of trying to do this in the Northern Territory, we risk turning human beings into disposable items and turning human life into a plastic, throwaway commodity. Compared to the holocaust and to the killing fields, what is happening in the Northern Territory at the moment is, perhaps, a very small outrage. We could not stop those other things. We can stop this. We must stop it. We cannot allow it to happen here in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Ross, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In his speech to the parliament opening the case for opposition to the Euthanasia Laws Bill, the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) set out a challenge to those of us who support it. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I invite anyone to mount a plausible argument that patients should not determine their course of treatment, whatever its form.

That is an invitation I now propose to accept. I intend to do so by a refutation of the four principal arguments advanced by the supporters of euthanasia, with special reference to the propositions advanced by two of the principal opponents of this bill, my colleagues the member for Grayndler and the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus).

Those propositions are: first, that the bill represents an illegitimate exercise of power by the Commonwealth; second, that the majority of people want euthanasia; third, that the bill involves the imposition of values by one group of people over another; and, fourth, that the bill denies individual rights and autonomy. In relation to the first argument, my colleague the member for Hindmarsh asked:
What right have we as a democratically elected parliament to overturn the properly enacted legislation of another legitimate and democratically elected parliament?

I share the view of the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) that this is in fact the weakest of all arguments advanced against the bill. It is, in the words of the previous speaker, the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), a cop‐out. The answer to the member's question is simple and I propose to deal with it in one sentence. This bill involves an entirely orthodox exercise of a specific Commonwealth power under section 122 of the Australian constitution.

The second argument advanced against the bill is that the majority of Australians want euthanasia. As a person with a great respect for the democratic process, and as someone who recognises that it is based upon a great sensitivity and concern for the will of the people, this is an argument which carries some force with me. I have received approximately 100 letters from my constituents on the subject of euthanasia of which about 90 have been supportive of the Andrews bill. I nonetheless accept that a majority of Australians, when polled in public opinion polls, would support euthanasia.

To oppose the will of the majority under these circumstances is said to be a symptom of arrogance. That, in my view, reflects a misconception about the role of the legislator and the duty of a parliamentarian in a representative democracy. The question of one's obligations to advance and reflect the views of one's constituents, as opposed to one's conscience, was addressed by Edmund Burke in a speech to the electors of Bristol, on his election to the House of Commons in 1774. He said:

Certainly, Gentlemen, it ought to be the happiness and glory of a representative to live in the strictest union, the closest correspondence, and the most unreserved communication with his constituents. Their wishes ought to have great weight with him; their opinions, high respect; their business, unremitted attention.

But his unbiased opinion, his mature judgement, his enlightened conscience, he ought not to sacrifice to you, to any man, or to any set of men living. These he does not derive from your pleasure—no, nor from the law and the Constitution. They are a trust from Providence, for the abuse of which he is deeply answerable. Your representative owes you, not his industry only, but his judgement; and he betrays instead of serving you, if he sacrifices it to your opinion.

Ours is not a direct democracy, such as that practised in the Swiss cantons, but a representative democracy, with members drawn from 148 electorates and six states and two territories. We are answerable to our constituents at each election but also to our conscience each day. While we respect and revere the individual wishes of our constituents, we are bound to exercise our judgment, flawed as it may be, to govern in the interests of the community as a whole. So there are circumstances in which it is not only allowable but indeed one's duty to oppose the majority, and I will now defend my decision to do so on this occasion.

A second objection to the bill expressed by my colleague, the member for Hindmarsh, is that it imposes the belief system of one group of people on another. This proposition is based on either considerable naivety or deliberate duplicity about the manner in which legislation operates. It suggests that it is possible, indeed desirable, to create legislation which is value free, which somehow can be evacuated of moral content. That is not my understanding of the way in which legislation works. Every piece of legislation passed by any parliament anywhere in the world involves value judgments and their compulsory enforcement by a legal instrument. That is the nature of legislation and, indeed, of decisions of courts throughout the land. Our task is not to somehow evacuate the law of moral content; our task is to ensure, according to the lights which guide each one of us, that the moral content in every law is worth enforcing.

A third argument advanced against this bill is that it denies individual rights. I accept that that is the case and that, in fact, the passage of every piece of legislation involves the circumscription of individual rights to some extent. The question is whether the sacrifice of individual freedom in these circumstances is required to achieve a greater social or communal objective, because the reality is that individual rights do not exist in a vacuum. They are given by a community, by a society, and if we erode the values which hold the society together then the very concept of individual dignity loses all meaning. Dignity is itself an inherently communal concept. There is no sense in which dignity can operate in isolation, so we have got to preserve the values which uphold community and society while, at the same time, exercising concern for the individual.
An opponent of this bill, the member for Grayndler, made this statement:
The opponents of voluntary euthanasia should not see it as a threat to their rights. Indeed this act has no application to them.

He was referring to the Northern Territory act. I find that an extraordinary statement—the idea that a piece of legislation can be applied merely to those who fall directly within its purview, that it merely regulates a technical exercise of behaviour by specified individuals.

The reality is that legislation on statute books around the country involves a snapshot of the values of the culture as a whole. The idea that we can somehow isolate ourselves or make ourselves immune from the influence of those values is, in my view, quite preposterous. So I entirely concur with the member for Melbourne, who said:

I think this fits in with a pattern that is extending right across our whole polity, right across many decisions to reduce people to atoms, to individuals, to take decisions that are not based on the society as a whole.
I listened yesterday with interest to the speech of my colleague the member for Boothby (Dr Southcott) when he quoted the great English poet John Donne, who said:
Any man's death diminishes me, because I am involved in Mankind; And therefore never send to know for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for thee.

This vision of connectedness, of community, of each belonging to the other is, in my view, the very heartbeat of what we are seeking to encourage as national leaders. It goes to the core of what civil society is all about. It is a foundation stone of every great ethical and legal code known to man.

It is reflected in the decision of Donoghue v. Stephenson, perhaps the most influential common law judgment of modern times, in which Lord Atkin articulated what has become known as the neighbour principle. He was drawing upon the remarks of a Jewish carpenter in northern Palestine about 20 centuries ago who was asked, `What is the greatest commandment in the law?' To this he responded:
All the law and the prophets can be summarised in this one command—love your neighbour as yourself.

The erosion of those values is reflected in some comments made during the debate. It was suggested, for example, by the member for Hindmarsh that doctors are killing their patients and that this is done without regulation and without due process. She went on to say:
Any country which respects law cannot allow killing to go on unsupervised.
And the member for Grayndler said:
Sometimes if a doctor cannot or will not assist this situation gives rise to clumsy and tragic suicide attempts.

The message to the Australian people is that if we are going to kill each other, let's do it according to the book; if we are going to kill each other, let's do it with efficiency. I find it somewhat ironic that that is coming from the member for Grayndler, who criticises the government on the basis of its preoccupation with efficiency. This argument is not about efficiency; it is about human life. We have got to uphold life. I support this bill and urge other honourable members to do the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There is little doubt in my mind that this debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill is a defining moment in our moral and social history. In fact, the implications go well beyond Canberra in 1996; they go out to the wider international community. We are being asked whether or not we sanction the taking of a life of one individual by another. We can dress up this issue in soft and soothing images; we can even attach it to a computer. But, inevitably, we are led to the inexorable, unavoidable reality that one human actively kills another. Call it euthanasia, suicide, assisted suicide or mercy killing, the intent and the results are still the same.

SPEECH.PARA: You must then ask yourself these questions. Is this consistent with human development over the last three or four millennia? Is it consistent with the rule of law that we have developed in our system over the last 900 years or so? Is it consistent with the development of ethics? Is it consistent with the mores of the Judaeo‐Christian tradition? Clearly, it is not. Let me clearly state that I am not judgmental, nor do I have any right to be judgmental of those who in good conscience subscribe to the concept of euthanasia, nor of those who in good conscience have chosen euthanasia or assisted in euthanasia.

It genuinely hurts and grieves me to be at odds with my colleagues in the Northern Territory. I wish it were otherwise. But I must observe that I find it a great irony that such a young, vibrant, enthusiastic territory—indeed, one which is full of life—would be the first in the civilised world to legalise the taking of life by another. As the Herald‐Sun put it in its 28 June editorial:

The Territory Government is now characterising this opposition as a fight over state rights. This is a great pity. Having forced the rest of the nation to think about this sensitive social issue, it cannot be surprised if the debate has spread beyond its borders.
Quite clearly, section 122 of our constitution gives the right to this parliament and that right must be exercised.

As colonies have developed, whether they have been British, French, Spanish or Portuguese, they have had various levels of social development that have taken them from colonies to dependencies, dominions, self‐governing dominions and countries. Papua New Guinea has gone through that process with Australia and so has the Northern Territory. For that reason, it is not conscionable for the federal government to duck this issue. This is one of our great defining moments and the federal government should be speaking about it.

I believe it goes beyond states rights. It is literally the ultimate life and death issue. If this form of death is approved there is no knowing the ultimate end of many variations that might follow it. In the 20th century we have lived in an age of experimentation and testing the limits. We have developed nuclear science to the point where we could have almost annihilated the human race. We have developed explosive devices capable of extraordinary violence. We have made chemicals capable of unimaginable devastation. Please God, many of these evils are back in their bottles, never to be released. Indeed, as individuals we are somewhat powerless to directly influence the course of their development.

But here today, with all our frailties and anxieties, we are capable of influencing this step towards a new dark age where life will become a currency to be haggled over, traded and devalued. Dare I say that some of us will become like the old one‐ and two‐cent coins—humble, insignificant, perceived to be valueless—and taken out of circulation.

Any reading of Australian history carries with it an insight into our capacity for endurance beyond unimagined odds. Whether it was the new colony on the edge of starvation in the 1780s, or Burke and Wills, or a plethora of other explorers, or goldminers and diggers, or pioneers, life was on the edge on many occasions. But it was still held to be sacred, inviolate and to be preserved at all cost. In the prisoner of war camps of the Second World War, men were subjected to unimaginable cruelty, brutality, starvation and deprivation, and yet in that pit, that morass of hopelessness, there was a common thread of defiance, endurance and caring for human life exhibited. From the Weary Dunlops through to the humblest privates, it is etched in our national character. It distinguishes us from all other nations.

Our respect for life extends to the opposition to capital punishment. We recoil from execution, some of us on humanitarian grounds, some because we will not allow the remotest possibility that an innocent life should be taken. Against this background, I see euthanasia as totally inconsistent with our national character and national mores.

Let me be quite clear on what I do not see as euthanasia. It is not the turning off of a life support machine for the brain dead, or the compliance with the wishes of a patient that excessive, onerous and intrusive mechanisms be not kept on. Surely, such people have the right to have them turned off and let nature take its course. Nor is it the administration of pain killing drugs where the unintended consequence may be the hastening of death. I see none of those as euthanasia. I see euthanasia as the active participation of one person, by injection or some other means, in taking another's life.

My concern is not only with what purports to be the strict controls in this Northern Territory legislation, but what might happen a little further down the track. I do not want to introduce abortion to this debate, nor shall I. But I do want to draw one parallel, and that is this: once abortion in some form was approved in one state, from that day to this the boundaries have been progressively pushed out until we have one so‐called eminent ethicist who believes that it is tolerable for parents to snuff out the lives of their babies in the early weeks of life. That is the extremity to which that debate was pushed. There is no doubt in my mind that the extremities of this debate, if approved, would be pushed out.

John Herron told a very interesting story in a speech he gave about an 89‐year‐old woman who was vomiting blood from a stomach ulcer. She was in imminent danger of death but she recoiled from the thought of an operation. She asked John Herron to ring her daughter. He rang the daughter and the daughter said that her mother was declining and he should let her die in peace. The woman's condition became critical. John rang her again, asking, `What do you think?' She repeated the advice, saying, `Let her die in peace.' However, the patient then decided to go ahead with the operation. She left hospital five days later a healthy and fit person. But the aftermath of this story is more chilling that the actual medical side of it. The medical side proves quite conclusively that not all people who are in danger of death should necessarily be shut down. Quite the contrary. What he found out later was—and this was on Mothers Day and all, would you believe—that the mother and daughter were estranged. The daughter was heavily in debt and the mother had a very large estate. And those are the sorts of circumstances where the boundaries would be pushed and the rationale for recommending death would be tested.

Let me take you a little further. I can see a circumstance where there would not be two doctors and a psychiatrist looking after every case. Some states would say that that was unnecessary, that they did not have enough psychiatrists, or that it militated against country people. What then would happen to Mary McGinty, in bed 30 of a 30‐bed ward, who had no family, where the bed was wanted, where she had no quality of life, where her carer decided that it was about time she went, and two compliant young house doctors agreed with her. Poor old Mary McGinty's life would be worth nothing.
Many in this debate have quoted John Donne's famous lines:
No man is an Island . . . Any man's death diminishes me . . . it tolls for thee.

The bell is tolling for life and for the rule of law. That bell can be the clearest possible clarion for the celebration of life, or it can toll for a new dark age. I intend to support the Andrews bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on the euthanasia debate, brought on by the Kevin Andrews private member's bill. From the outset, I must say that I have given this bill, the Euthanasia Laws Bill, a very detailed consideration on obviously what is fundamentally a life and death issue. The decision that I have arrived at has not been made in haste, nor do I wish to pass judgment on those who, with great passion, have advocated euthanasia. On this note, I do have great empathy with the predicament that my Northern Territory colleagues find themselves in—notably, Nick Dondas and Grant Tambling—regarding the support for the Northern Territory's right of the terminally ill legislation.

BREAK.PARA: It is important to define, though, what the true definition of euthanasia is, and to acknowledge the distinction between passive and active euthanasia. Generally speaking, euthanasia is the intentional taking of a person's life for compassionate motives when the person requests it. It is the administration of a lethal injection which terminates life. This is distinct from passive euthanasia, which is the removal of a life support system, or the withdrawal of a medical treatment which is necessary to support life. One is the actual killing of life; the other is letting nature take its course. The Northern Territory's legislation, the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act—whilst in theory it sounds plausible and, to be fair, there are numerous checks and balances—cannot be condoned because the risks are too great. I will demonstrate that history has proven it to be so.
The proponents of euthanasia argue that the individual has a right to choose and there is merit in this argument, as we live in a free and democratic society. However, as I quote the House of Lords:
The issue of euthanasia is one in which the interests of the individual cannot be separated from the interests of society as a whole.

I acknowledge that there are individual cases in which euthanasia may seem to be more appropriate, but individual cases cannot reasonably establish the foundation of a policy which would have such serious and widespread repercussions in the broader community.

There are many examples in Australia where the state does override individual rights. One example is the speed limits on our roads. Individuals have the right to drive a car but, in the interests of the wider community, the state restricts people to speed limits. Another more recent example is the gun legislation, where many law‐abiding citizens were asked to forgo their individual right to own a firearm, which gave society, as a whole, the right to build a safer and more secure society.

In many ways, it is exactly the same with euthanasia, as I will demonstrate. It is the vulnerable and elderly who need to be protected by legislation from, perhaps, overzealous family members, doctors, financial institutions, and even themselves, if they are clinically depressed or mentally ill. It should also be noted that the overriding principle in the Judaeo‐Christian culture which has dominated most of the Western world is the principle of the sanctity of life and the need to preserve human life. This culture of life, not death, is not only endorsed by religious teachings but also, most importantly, by the medical fraternity by the Hippocratic oath. We already have an alarming rate of youth suicide in this country, so why should the state be sanctioning death as a preferred option to life?

In my view, whilst I empathise with the notion of euthanasia and the right of the individual to choose, in reality it should not be allowed because it can lead to abuses. The most vulnerable people, not just the old but those who are disadvantaged, whether through poverty, race, physical or mental disability, are gravely at risk of being euthanised. There are checks and balances in the Northern Territory legislation, but it is also seriously flawed. No checks and balances can protect people from such things as severe mental illness or clinical depression following the announcement of a terminal illness. Checks and balances for these conditions are only as strong as the health system which diagnoses them. In many cases around Australia, I would not like to bet my life on some of the local health systems.

Providing the option of euthanasia could bring undue pressure on people who are ill or terminally ill. Instead of focusing on those precious days, weeks or months, and indeed perhaps a full recovery through adequate medical treatment, technological development or palliative care, many patients understandably may seek to take the easy option, more because of the fear of the unknown. In many cases the twilight zone for the terminally ill patients can be a very rewarding period in their lives which can be without suffering through palliative care or the administration of morphine and other drugs. Certainly it is society's responsibility to provide care facilities for these people, the disadvantaged within the community groups, rather than perhaps the abuse of euthanasia. I am particularly concerned with nursing homes or hospitals where economic rationalism may tend to drive budgets by freeing up overcrowded wards and cutting corners in an attempt to process terminally ill patients through the system.

The risk is that by legalising euthanasia it will place a dollar value on life rather than focus on providing adequate care for those individuals. We as a society would be sending a wrong signal to the community. Many speakers have spoken about the Netherlands example, but I do feel it would be remiss of me not to quote that it is revealed in Dutch findings that up to 27 per cent of people who were given a lethal injection had neither expressed consent nor had knowledge of the impending lethal injection. These statistics in themselves are enough to reconsider the inherent risk of individuals or doctors making poor decisions under undue pressure.

All religious groups—as Kevin Andrews said in his speech—Aboriginal people and the vast majority of medical practitioners have rejected euthanasia. The underlying unifying principle is that people who are most at risk are the most vulnerable and a law which fails to protect the most vulnerable is always a bad law.

I would like to pass on my personal experience in the passing of my grandmother where my mother, my uncle and my aunt cared for her more than she cared for life. There were times when my grandmother felt a burden to her brothers and to her daughters and loved ones. Understandably these feelings could fluctuate each day, from feeling like a major burden one day to being a member of a loving family the next. Certainly, having euthanasia could bring on rapid decision making for these individuals.

I would also like to raise the administrative problems of law enforcement in the case of abuse. Just as medical opinions vary from doctor to doctor, I am sure problems of litigation and allegations of abuse could arise. Doctors already have enough risk of litigation to deal with, without adding the risk of facing allegations of murder.

Regarding opinion polls, there are those people who do not believe this is an issue which should be subject to a conscience vote and who call for a referendum on this issue. I give you the proportion of letters that have come into my office on this issue. To date I have received over 90 letters against euthanasia and seven letters for euthanasia. Although this is not an authoritative indication of the wishes of my electorate, it certainly is a barometer of a considerable opinion of local thought. Past examples have shown me that many measures of public opinion can be distorted without the correct question being asked.

Finally, there is the issue of states rights. I do not believe that states rights is an issue because we are dealing with a territory where the Commonwealth has always had constitutional power. It is written in black and white in our constitution. Whilst I empathise with Northern Territory law makers, the Commonwealth has used these constitutional powers in many cases before, notably with the Tasmanian privacy legislation. As Kevin Andrews said in his speech, the territories, just like the states, do have the responsibility to protect the ill and the vulnerable. There have been plenty of cases where the Commonwealth has overridden the states, notably that of the privacy bill which overrode the legislation in Tasmania.
I commend the Kevin Andrews bill to the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking against legislated euthanasia, I do not wish to denigrate or undermine those who are in favour of it. No doubt, they are very sincere in their belief that such an act will relieve people of pain and misery. However, it should be remembered that this act is final: it extinguishes the flame of life; it can never be reversed.

SPEECH.PARA: In talking on the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, I want to stress that euthanasia is interpreted to mean different things to different people. Some refer to it as mercy killing, whilst others see it as a state sanctioned deliberate killing of one person by another, and yet others describe it as physician assisted suicide. We use the terms passive voluntary euthanasia and active voluntary euthanasia. These terms are used very frequently, but again they are very open to varying interpretations.

Brian Pollard, who in 1992 commenced the first full‐time service in a general hospital in Sydney for the care of the dying, wrote in his book, The challenge of euthanasia, certain aspects in which he very clearly demonstrated that euthanasia should not be legalised as it is impossible to remove sources of abuse. In the same book, reference is made to Holland where euthanasia is tolerated but remains illegal by statute law. Here the annual death rate from euthanasia is as high as 23,000 and this number includes many examples of abuse of the recommended safeguards and extensions to non‐voluntary euthanasia.

The legal, moral and ethical questions surrounding euthanasia are complex and can be very confusing, not only to ordinary people in our community but also to many professionals in both the health and the legal fields. Only yesterday, we read in our newspapers that Mr Rod Dent, the son of the first person to die by legally sanctioned euthanasia in Australia, has now withdrawn his support for the continuation of such a practice.

The Northern Territory legislation legalises euthanasia for those who can demonstrate that they are terminally ill. The question arises however, how does one determine terminally ill? Is it a person suffering from advanced stages of dementia? Is it a person suffering from advanced cancer? Is it a person suffering from severe brain injury yet still in control of bodily functions? The questions are many but, again, the definition is not precise. Pain or suffering takes many forms. Today, palliative care provides excellent relief and can be administered both in institutions such as hospitals and hospices and also in the comfort of a person's own home.

At this point, I would like to pay tribute to the dedicated and tireless work carried out by administrators of palliative care. These people, both in the paid professional field as well as volunteers, are extremely committed in their work ensuring that their patients' pain is eased and their suffering controlled. I commend them for their dedication to humanity.

In my opinion, what is required in every state in Australia is more input and further research to ensure that the standard of palliative care is constantly improved and that every person seeking such care will have equal and easy access to avail himself or herself of this. Enhancing the promotion and awareness of palliative care programs is, in my opinion, extremely necessary. I say this because I believe that palliative care allows people to die with dignity and, in most cases today, free of pain when they reach the end of their natural life. As a health professional, I have witnessed people die in various states of suffering. I have also witnessed the wonderful expressions of peace and contentment on patients' faces when, as a result of receiving palliative care, suffering was relieved.

BREAK.PARA: At this stage, I would like to quote an excerpt from Dr McCullough who, in her report, Putting people down, printed in May 1996, stated:
The right to life, whatever its quality, is universal and sacred among humankind. Those who genuinely want to die will find a way to suicide without assistance.

In a civilised society, respect for life is fundamental. So is respect for the aged, the disabled and the mentally ill. Making euthanasia legal places those among us who are vulnerable into an even more vulnerable position.
For approximately the past 2,000 years, people qualified to provide medical assistance have been bound by the Hippocratic oath which states in part as follows:
I will give no deadly medicine to anyone if asked.

Thus, to legalise euthanasia in any form, would directly impact on people's understanding of what constitutes medical treatment and how we perceive medicine should be practised. Man has always thought of doctors as healers. Indeed it is the ethical duty of every doctor to accept full responsibility for the care and wellbeing of their patients.

I stated at the beginning of my speech that the issue we are debating today is complex. There are social, religious, philosophical and legal aspects to be considered. But these arguments will take much more than the time allocated for me here today to articulate. Therefore, I have outlined only a few reasons as to why legalised euthanasia should not be supported.
In speaking for the Kevin Andrews bill, I wish to conclude by stressing the fact that current research suggests that every model proposed to legalise euthanasia has thus far been shown to be flawed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson, Michael, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RONALDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been an enormous amount said in this debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 and I am not going to go over the ground covered by many other speakers. I just really want to talk about this from a personal point of view. I can say that in my 13 years in public life—seven here and six in local government—there has never been a more difficult decision that I have had to come to. I will go through the reasons for those difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: The first one is that I have absolutely no doubt that by casting my conscience vote, which I will be doing strongly in support of the Kevin Andrews bill, I am acutely aware that I am supporting the views of only some of my constituents, and that is difficult. I have no idea, and no way of knowing, whether my view is the majority view of my constituents. I suspect it is. But suspecting and knowing are two entirely different things. It may well be said that we are indeed making those sorts of decisions on a daily basis, that, as MPs, we are making decisions, voting on legislation downstairs, where we cannot ever know what the true majority view of our constituents is.

But the difference between those numerous divisions that I have been to or, where there has been no division, where a bill has been supported and this one is that in all my seven years, which is coming up in March, not one of them has involved the potential taking of life. That is what really sets aside this conscience vote and this bill from anything else that has confronted me and, I suspect, my colleagues behind me, including the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), who has been here a lot longer than I have. I suspect that this is probably the first time he has had to vote on life. I want to make it very clear that this is an entirely different debate from the ones that we normally have in this place.

BREAK.PARA: I am supporting this bill for a number of reasons. I have personal significant discomfort with the concept of euthanasia. It is a personal view and very much a personal view and it is not based on reading scientific journals. It is not based on listening to the excellent arguments from both sides of this debate that we have had over the last three weeks. Rather it is a view formed from the heart. Whether there is room in the political system in the 1990s for something coming from the heart, I do not know, but in this particular case this is very much an issue that comes from the heart.

There are several other matters that I am extremely concerned about. A debate about euthanasia is a debate about taking the most precious thing that we all have and that we all share, and that is life. For the whole Australian community not to be involved in that, I think, is very dangerous and it is one of the other reasons that I am supporting the Andrews bill.

As I mentioned before, I believe that a conscience vote is totally inappropriate. It is inappropriate that I am standing here making decisions on behalf of nearly 80,000 good people in my electorate. I believe they deserve the right to be participants in a debate about something as serious as this, and they are not. If this debate continues after it is transferred back into the main chamber, I believe that it is essential that all Australian people have the right to vote on something as important and basic as this—and we are talking about life.

Like others, I have seen two close relations—people whom I have been extraordinarily close to—die the most appalling deaths. I suspect that those two people especially would have wanted me to support this bill because I believe that they believed in life. I think the longevity of life and the ability of an individual to extend their life as long as is humanly possible was very important to them.

For people to have the ability to forum shop for death—I know there are varying views about whether or not this is the right way to discuss this issue—or, if you like, forum shop for the taking of life, is something that I also find absolutely abhorrent. That is why I reiterate my views about the necessity for the Australian people to vote on this if it ever comes to that stage. It is totally wrong, in my view, for one small segment of the Australian community to have input into something as important as this.

I have an apology to make and that is to the people in my electorate who do not share my views on this. I do apologise to them. I hope that they realise that this has been an extraordinarily difficult debate for me, personally, and, I suspect, for every other member of this House. I hope that they will judge me not on the decision that I have made, but on the reasons for reaching that decision. I do apologise to them. I want them to know why I passionately support the Kevin Andrews bill. As I said before, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is about something absolutely basic—and that is life. I thank you for the opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl, Garry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Like so many of my colleagues, I have found this issue to be an extremely difficult one. It is fair to say that I have agonised over it very deeply. We have to consider what we are and what we are here for. People commonly talk about politicians—frequently with some other adjective added to it. They very rarely talk about parliamentarians. I have to say to the committee that I was born disposed to being a parliamentarian.

SPEECH.PARA: As a young man I read everything I could about Pitt, Disraeli and Gladstone and the history of parliamentary democracy. I can still recall that when, as a very young man, I first entered a parliamentary chamber—the Legislative Assembly in Macquarie Street—my blood tingled. And I can say that when I come into our chamber my blood still tingles, because we are the inheritors of so much struggle, so much difficulty and death, to achieve the level of parliamentary democracy that we have here.

As well as reading about those early British prime ministers I mentioned, I was also incredibly influenced as a young man by Sir Winston Churchill and Robert Menzies who I believe were the ultimate in parliamentarians. So my whole attitude to being here has been dictated and dominated by a desire to be a parliamentarian, not just a politician. If it were possible to have as my epitaph `He was a parliamentarian', as far as I am concerned that would be enough.

If one were just a politician, one could take a very easy answer to the question and say, `Yes, I will vote for the bill of the member for Menzies.' I am not suggesting for one moment that those who do vote for it are the lesser parliamentarians for it, from a purely political viewpoint. But I am afraid that, after a great deal of thought about it, I cannot vote for it. I wish to particularly thank the people in my electorate who were so very kind as to advise me of their views. Quite a lot of people wrote; a lot of people did not write but took opportunities at meetings, or when I was doing the shopping at Woolworths, to talk to me personally and tell me their views.

I am not overly influenced by the public opinion polls. After all, it is like when an election is on—there is only one poll that counts, and that is when the votes are counted. Equally, I must confess to a little amusement at some of the letters I received, because they were form letters and still had the admonition on the bottom saying, `Write this out in your own handwriting. Don't use the form letter.' But I do thank those people in the community who did write and tell me their views.

The situation is that when the Northern Territory was granted self‐government in 1978, the Northern Territory parliament was given power to make laws over all matters except four areas—industrial relations, uranium mining, Aboriginal land rights and Uluru and Kakadu national parks—and the Commonwealth retained a safeguard of being able to veto any legislation within six months of any law being passed. With the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act, that six months passed and nobody took any action. The government of the day took no action, the opposition did not attempt to take any action, and the member for Menzies took no action.

What I have to say is that my very deep feeling is that this bill does not really address the question of euthanasia. I must make it quite clear—very clear—I am not an advocate of euthanasia. I regard all human life as being sacred. I am totally opposed to capital punishment. But while this bill is aimed at amending the Northern Territory (Self‐Government) Act 1978, the Australian Capital Territory (Self‐Government) Act 1988 and the Norfolk Island Act 1979, it is not a bill to remove the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. It is a bill to retrospectively say that the Northern Territory did not have the right to make that law. That is my sticking point; I cannot surmount that. To this extent, I believe—and I say this with the greatest goodwill to my friend Kevin Andrews—the bill is a sham.

The bill will not achieve what people think it is going to achieve. There are many people throughout our community who are actively supporting the Andrews bill, but it is not going to achieve what they want it to achieve. I think that a great many people who are against it for other reasons will eventually come to see that it will not achieve what they are seeking either.

BREAK.PARA: If we pass this bill, we introduce legislative discrimination against some citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia. If we do this, we are making every citizen in an Australian territory a second‐class citizen. From the whole basis of my life and my interest in life, I cannot do this. As far as I am concerned, we have to be absolutely non‐discriminatory in our approach to Australian citizens. I say this, too, in the context of the debate that has been sparked by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). We have to be non‐discriminatory and, by and large, we are. As an aside, I think we, as Australians, can be very proud of our country, our tolerance and our understanding—in fact, we have a lot to be proud of.

I cannot concur with federal intervention in the lawful activities of a democratic government, a democratic parliamentary assembly of this nation. I would have hoped that the issue of euthanasia could have been addressed in some other way. I note that, in the closing paragraphs of his submission, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) said:
The legislation is such that I would like it withdrawn and redrafted—and I have half a mind to move an amendment to that effect.
If the right honourable gentleman finds the other half of his mind to put with the first half, I would be very pleased to support him. It is a vitally important issue.

I am a passionate and totally dedicated supporter of federalism in this country of ours; I am a passionate supporter of our constitution. I cannot accept that we will pass legislation which, as I said, will discriminate against some citizens of Australia. I did say to some of my constituents very early on that I would vote against euthanasia, but this bill is not about euthanasia. This bill is about a diminution of the Commonwealth of Australia and the federal system of Australia, and about the equal application of all rights for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I state at the outset that I am opposing the Andrews private member's bill, the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, and casting a vote in support of the legislation which has been enacted by the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. In doing so, I acknowledge the nature of this debate. It is a conscience vote. It is one of those rare occasions when we, as members of the House of Representatives—nearly all elected within the protocols of party discipline—are free to exercise our vote without regard to party policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I make no pretence that my vote is anything more than that. It is my own view representing totally my personal judgment. I do not pretend in any way that my judgment has been canvassed, either through my party political policy processes, or in any way with my broad constituency. It is a personal conscience vote and I do not wish to represent it in any other way.

In reaching my personal conclusions, I know that there are many more learned than I who have made a different judgment, not the least being Barry Jones, a man whose intellect and foresightedness are widely respected in this nation. I have studied his contribution to this debate in depth and find that from the same facts and judgments I draw a different conclusion. My reasoning is relatively simple. I do not see the Northern Territory legislation in the way that it is portrayed by some. It is legislation which allows a person to take his or her decision and, albeit it is assisted, enact that decision individually. If one believes in the personal right to exercise choice, and I do—and I certainly want it for myself, and for my father—then there is no real choice unless there are dignified, highly caring and quality means to exercise that choice. This is what I believe the Northern Territory has done and I congratulate them for doing so.

BREAK.PARA: I would make a couple of other points. I do not have any illusions about the capacity of mankind to take the next step, turning voluntary—in fact, requested—action to bring one's life to an end, into a process of tidying up problems with the aged and infirm citizens, and relatives. I fully understand the arguments that the next step is an easy one to take and I agree that that is so. But I say in this parliament right now that I will fight as hard as I have to to prevent a move to that next step, and that is the adoption of euthanasia policy issues by governments or by people that mean that people are facing involuntary choices. I would do that just as firmly as I support the aims of the current Northern Territory legislation, which provides what I choose to call assisted passage, which is your personal choice. I do not see it as a states rights issue.

I find it just one of the paradoxes of politics that in my party on our side of the House we do not have the dilemma of the issue of states' rights. We are an overtly federalist party. We understand and accept and, in fact, we demand the right of the Commonwealth government to intervene in the affairs of the states where it thinks it is required. It is many on the other side of the House who have personal dilemmas with that. So in this case, I find myself supporting the legislation of the Northern Territory, finding it strange that the reverse argument about the rights of the territory to make legislation is being used by many on the other side. But that is the nature of this debate. It is one that does not fit tidily into any of our conventional policy notions or structures. In fact, it is almost a complete juxtaposition of those issues. But I am making it clear that in supporting the Northern Territory legislation in this way, I am not conceding my personal view that the Commonwealth has an overriding role and power and so I am not raising in the debate in any way the argument that I believe the Commonwealth has the right, or that the Northern Territory rights come into it. It is not an issue which I think enters it all.

I guess it finally comes down to, when we exercise a conscience vote in this place, I do not know what rules to operate by. The only ones I can come to are, `Do unto others as you would have them do unto you', or `Practise what you preach'. In my own case, I very firmly want the right, providing I am capable, to make that choice for myself and I want the right for my father to be able to make it, because he is my only living relative who might come to this point in the not too distant future. I would want him to have the right to make a choice. If I want it for me and my family, then I have to be prepared to want it for the Australian people—and I do. That is the sole basis on which I have reached this conclusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Andrea, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this most sensitive issue of euthanasia as a response to concerns felt by me and within the electorate of Bowman. Of all the written and spoken responses to the current legislation that have been received by me, the overwhelming concern has been drawn to the fact that the deliberate act of terminating any life is abhorrent and not fitting the vast majority of community opinion.

SPEECH.PARA: The response to this issue has been, for many people, an opportunity to voice their concern about bureaucratic decisions that have impacted on their own personal experience, or worry about the consequences that this legislation will have further down the track. Some of the concerns raised include comments such as `Where will it stop?'; `Respect for all human life from the womb to the tomb is the very foundation of all civilised society'; `A society that deliberately kills certain of its members is basically very sick'; `The devaluation of human life in our country has become quite worrying'; and `There are countless ways this legislation could and would be abused'. These are but a few of the statements that I have received. My response has been by way of a general reply. However, I have taken all their considerations on board.

If there were a measure of how compassionate a community is perceived to be, I would have to say that that measure would be how we treat our weakest and most vulnerable members of the community. The frail elderly, long‐term chronically ill and the terminally ill should feel no doubt that a government that represents the collective goodwill of the Australian populace has their best interests at heart. As a matter of conscience, I have no doubt in reassuring those in acute care that the provision of palliative care—appropriate, tender and supportive assistance—will be provided for those in the sunset days of their lives.

By denying the opportunity to show a caring and compassionate response to the dying we, as humanly responsible arbiters, would become inhumane and hard hearted, dispassionate and aloof from the very essential nature of ourselves. To dispose of a human life through a bureaucratic process of consultation, along with an array of professional care givers assigning the approval for dispatching of a patient to a document, is looming on the horizon as a bizarre aberration of the death and dying process.

While not denying an individual's right to terminate their own suffering, state sanctioned murder is not what I believe we, as parliamentarians, were elected to ratify. It is essentially against the basic instincts of preservation of the species that a medical practitioner would assist in extinguishing a life by bureaucratic decree. If we are to be, to be seen to be and to endeavour to be a caring and compassionate society, we have to maintain a sensitive and appropriate regimen in the provision of palliative care for those aged and dying.

Health care workers, ministers of religion and those who have travelled the journey towards life's end with a loved one or a patient have all expressed to me the fact that at no time did any of these people ask to be relieved of life. In other words, although they knew they were dying, those in care appreciated all the efforts and intentions of all care givers and relations.

It is unfortunate that palliative care was not an option for those who have already determined their very public termination of life. The need for the provision of palliative care in the Northern Territory is a glaring flaw in this whole scenario.

We as a society have come a long way from the dawn of time, through countless ages of turmoil, change, progress and evolution to arrive at a place in time where the elected representatives of our great nation are deliberating on this life and death issue. It is of great significance and import that our considerations will either overturn the territory legislation or not, that inevitably the state approval for terminating one's life is allowed or not allowed.

The idea of states rights is not what I consider as important or as crucial to the whole debate as the right of any person, body, jurisdiction or government to deem a condition of life—that is, terminal illness—to be the reason to terminate a life earlier than as nature would have determined. That is tampering with natural justice.

What can be found now, already existing within those places that minister to the dying, is a sense of deep commitment and duty of care aimed at making those last days of a dying person's life comfortable, restful and pleasant.

I would hope that most people in this difficult time of life are drawn into the circle of care by health workers, doctors, relatives and friends who comfort and support those grieving and dying. After all, death comes to us all—only sooner to some than others. For those in protracted pain and facing terminal illness, a long established network and system for caring has developed. Governments even train people to assist those in need of acute care, intensive care, critical care, the aged, frail and the terminally ill. Do we wish to deny these people and those who have to cope with death and the dying, the opportunity to travel over life's last hurdle?

We are at one end of life's long journey, contemplating whether to assist a terminally ill patient to end their suffering and at the very same time spending time, energy and lots of money on endeavouring to prevent youth suicide and black deaths in custody, even though those groups have made a conscious decision to end their own short precious lives. Isn't this confusing?

What has been brought forward is the concept that desensitising of one's outlook on life and illness occurs when the right to terminate life occurs. We all know what happens to a horse with a broken leg, a dog that has reached at least 15 years, a diseased or feral cat or animal. They have all reached their use‐by date.

What the Northern Territory legislation attempts to do is put people in the same category as a diseased animal, only offer them, while they are still compos, the opportunity of a lifetime—instant death. The terminally ill do not really need to have this as an option. It would be more appropriate to offer the same circumstance to life‐sentenced criminals and to those who committed heinous crimes against humanity. They truly deserve to die.

Our terminally ill do not, and have not asked to be placed in such a circumstance where they could ask for early extinction. They deserve better than that. They deserve our best care, our greatest concern, our constant attention and our respect for the dignity afforded those who cannot help themselves, the ultimate acknowledgment of their condition and our time, our love and devotion. For these are the human elements of our existence, our display of sharing and caring. For these reasons, I commend Kevin Andrews' bill and will work towards overturning the Northern Territory legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews, Kevin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —May I take this opportunity in concluding this second reading debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill to commend all speakers who have participated in this debate for their contribution. As has been pointed out, all the political parties have granted their members a conscience vote because of the recognition that this is a matter of profound importance and a recognition that there are a range of sincerely held and differing views, many of which have been expressed in profound and in sometimes very moving ways in the debate in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a matter which is difficult because of the nature of the issue we are dealing with. It requires considerable thought and consideration, taking into account our own emotional experiences, the social circumstances of our communities in the nation in which we live, the role of laws in our society, and the consequences that changing the law will have both for Australians who live today and possibly those in the future.

When this matter was first raised, which seems a long time ago, it was said by many people, and by a range of media commentators in particular, that this would be a divisive debate; that there would be people taking different views in this parliament and there was some expectation that we might not talk to each other again because of those different views. Contrary to those assertions, what this debate has shown is that the members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth parliament can show great maturity and great tolerance towards differing views and opinions which are sincerely held about such a profound matter as this. Without in any sense wishing to be patronising to any of my colleagues, I want to say that I believe this debate, regardless of its outcome, has shown the great maturity that members of the Commonwealth parliament are capable of, something for which I commend all my colleagues—those who have spoken and those who have not.

So far as I am aware, members have been able to put their views freely and to have those views respected. Different views have been expressed by members of the same party right across the political spectrum and those views have been respected by all other members. Because the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) is in the chamber, I note that on this issue he and I obviously differ. But what I can say about him and about those who have taken a different view to mine in this debate is that I believe the way in which we have respected those views and been able to get on with the rest of the life of this place is something for which all can be commended.
