I do not wish to rehearse all the arguments that have been raised in this debate, but I do want to comment on one or two things. One is that quite a number of members expressed regret that this debate did not take place in the main chamber of the House of Representatives. I have said before, and I will say again for the public record, that I have considerable sympathy with that point of view. Secondly, although many members have spoken on this bill there has also been widespread discussion within the parties and over the last few months, through the organisation of seminars by the Parliamentary Library and through private initiatives, there have been occasions when members and senators have had an opportunity to listen to and have discussions with people who have particular views about this issue.

As an example, I recall a meeting and seminar arranged by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) at which the framer of the initial Northern Territory legislation, the Hon. Marshall Perron, was present and addressed his views about it. I also recall a seminar at which members of the Northern Territory Aboriginal community were able to express their views and discuss the matter with members of this place. I think that is indicative of the widespread discussion which has occurred.

What this bill has done, regardless of one's views ultimately about it, is engender a national debate about this issue; a national debate which, as I have said from the outset, I think is important. If there are going to be profound changes to the law in this country on a matter that goes to the life and death of the citizens of this nation, then it should only occur after there has been national debate. I am proud to have had some part to play in trying to raise that national debate.

I do not know what the outcome of the vote will be, but if the members of the House by a majority pass the bill and it goes to the Senate, then I would remind anybody reading these remarks that the Senate has established a committee to examine the bill in more detail. I encourage those Australians, whatever their view on this matter is, to make a submission to that committee because, in that way, democracy works at its best in this country.

I do not want to single out any contribution in particular, but I do want to say something about one matter which was raised in the debate: the proposed amendments that were foreshadowed by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Jones) in his contributions. In his thoughtful contribution, the honourable member for Lalor made suggestions about the enabling provisions of this bill.

That is the part of the bill that says that the legislative assemblies of the territories have the power to make laws about certain things which relate to the withdrawal or refusal of burdensome, unwanted or futile treatment. He suggested that, based on the experience of the refusal of treatment legislation in Victoria and South Australia, there ought to be an encouragement to the legislative assemblies to make laws for the appointment of an agent, by a patient, where that agent can then make treatment decisions for the patient if the patient should become incapable or incompetent and therefore unable to make those decisions. That is the state of law in Victoria and South Australia.

The member for Lalor also suggested that, through this bill, we ought to be encouraging those territories that have not done so to repeal their legal sanctions against attempted suicide. I indicated in discussions with the honourable member that nothing in the bill precluded the territories from making laws to that effect, but that I did not have any fundamental objection to actually setting out that encouragement in the terms of the bill itself.

I am simply indicating here that, after discussions with the honourable member for Lalor, I am minded to accept those two amendments which he is putting forward. They will be put forward in relation to each of the three territories which the bill relates to. That is further encouragement for the Northern Territory and the other territories to enact laws which are similar to the refusal of treatment legislation in Victoria, and similar legislation in South Australia.

At the outset, in the introductory first reading of this bill, I said that I believed there were two things that should be done in place of introducing legislation such as the Northern Territory's. The first is to introduce modern refusal of treatment legislation, as in Victoria and South Australia. I conclude by again encouraging that course.

Secondly, in this country we need to take note of the massive advances being made in relation to the provision of palliative care and the development of the specialities of palliative care medicine in this country and provide a national framework for that palliative care and for the increasing resourcing of palliative care services in this country.

I think those measures—on the one hand, the provision of modern refusal of treatment legislation; on the other hand, the proper resourcing of palliative care in this country—are measures which ultimately will do a great deal for people in the dying stages of their lives. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I intend to make a statement on this matter. On 8 October 1996, this bill was referred to the Main Committee for the remainder of the second reading stage up to, but not including, the putting of any question at the conclusion of the debate. The honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) has closed the debate by speaking in reply. Under standing order 68 the bill will be returned to the House with an unresolved question.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Mr Somlyay:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Report No. 346, entitled Guarding the independence of the Auditor‐General , is a most aptly named report from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, and I want to draw the attention of the parliament to some of the remarks that have been made within the report and to commend the committee for its work in producing the report. Firstly we find, in the foreword of the chairman, remarks to this effect:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the JCPA considers the independence of the Auditor‐General to be absolutely fundamental to public accountability in Australia. If the Auditor‐General is not properly resourced—or does not have a legislative mandate—to carry out an effective and broad scrutiny of the pubic sector, then Parliament itself is compromised in its ability to hold the Executive Government to account.

They are very apt and very well chosen words. The background to this report is that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) indicated, when he was Leader of the Opposition, that a Liberal government would establish `a completely independent Auditor‐General, so that a fearless and authoritative surveillance of government departments can occur without intimidation from the executive.' He went on to say that, under the coalition, the Auditor‐General would be an officer of the parliament. I guess that a large part of the work of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts was in determining how to give effect to the concept of making the Auditor‐General an officer of the parliament. Throughout the report there are a number of references to how this might be done and what its implications were.

The committee went on to say in its report that it regarded this inquiry as being of profound importance to public accountability in Australia and that it believed that the community expected the parliament to hold the executive to account for their use of public funds. Things such as disclosures of profligacy or fraud in the use of public moneys, or incompetence or inefficiency in the management of public services, naturally provoke public outrage; and the parliament in turn relies on the Auditor‐General to provide expert independent advice to help it to fulfil its function of scrutinising executive agencies.

According to the committee, the Auditor‐General performs a function which makes an important contribution to effective parliamentary scrutiny where the parliament itself lacks the technical expertise and resources to exercise the function. The committee went on to say that, if the parliament cannot ensure the independence of the Auditor‐General from the executive and if the executive can effectively inhibit the effective discharge of all its functions by starving the Auditor‐General of resources, then the chain of public accountability is broken.

The joint committee went on to say that the parliament and, in particular, the parliamentary committees which examine in detail the financial affairs and the performance of government agencies are becoming increasingly reliant on the Auditor‐General to hold the government of the day to account. The challenges to public accountability that we experience now, with the complexity of the arrangements by which governments deliver their services, can only be met with the assistance of a well‐equipped and fiercely independent Auditor‐General. They are very important remarks that have been made by the committee concerning the importance of the work of the Auditor‐General.

The report went on to make some remarks and recommendations concerning issues of tenure, dismissal, and reappointment, and indicated that under the Audit Act the Auditor‐General is appointed until age 65 and can only be dismissed for incapacity, incompetence or misbehaviour. This can only be done by the Governor‐General, following an address from each house of parliament in the same session of parliament. The committee heard evidence, from people of the stature of Sir Lenox Hewitt OBE and Mr John Nethercote, arguing strongly against anything which would change the tenure of the Auditor‐General and indicating their view that the independence of the Auditor‐General would be most adversely affected if there were changes to the tenure by way of a fixed term and to the capacity for reappointment, and things of that nature. There was great concern expressed about those possible changes.

If we move on to the committee's report on pages 23 and 24, we see that there were further remarks about the independence of the auditor and the importance of the Auditor‐General being able to determine his or her own priorities for investigation so they should not be subject to the executive in terms of the issues they investigate. The committee said it believes that:
The Auditor‐General, by the very nature of the position, develops breadth and depth of knowledge of public sector management, and is best placed to identify priorities for audit.
It went on to say:

It follows that it is essential for the Auditor‐General to have freedom to determine the audit programme of the ANAO, including the choice of bodies to be audited, the nature and scope of audits to be conducted, and whether the work will be carried out by the ANAO or contracted out to private enterprise.

Once again, the committee said that the Auditor‐General needed to be able to determine his or her own priorities. It made very important remarks about the issue of the appointment of the auditor. Quoting the Australasian Council of Auditors‐General it said:

It is a generally held principle that an auditee should not appoint the auditor because, in so doing, the independence or perceived independence of the auditor can be compromised. In the private sector this principle is buttressed by parliament's requirements that the shareholders of public companies, rather than the directors of the board or the executive, appoint the external auditor.

So they pointed out that if you want to make an analogous situation with the states or the Commonwealth, you are really looking at appointment by the parliament rather than by the executive. Indeed, this report makes significant recommendations in precisely that direction. It goes on to say:
The committee believes that the parliament should have a right of final approval in relation to the Auditor‐General and not just a right to be consulted.
The committee is also concerned that that process of appointment should not be unwieldy.

It is very timely that we get this report from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts because in Victoria we have the most extraordinary situation where the Victorian government has decided that government agencies might be able to appoint their own auditors, effectively bypassing the Victorian Auditor‐General. Premier Kennett has set up a review apparently with this objective in mind.

If we are going to talk about issues that relate to the independence of the Auditors‐General, it is worth having a look at what some of the experts in the field have suggested about this issue. For example, the New South Wales Auditor‐General, Mr Tony Harris, described moves to examine privatising the functions of Mr Ches Baragwanath, the Victorian Auditor‐General, as being in direct contrast to recommendations from royal commissions. Mr Harris said that both the Fitzgerald inquiry into police corruption in Queensland and the Western Australian Inc. royal commission had shown that private sector auditors had failed to locate significant corporate failures until after they had occurred. Neither royal commission contemplated that any government could act to weaken the strength of the Auditor‐General, Mr Harris said, and so using their logic, any weakening of the role of the Auditor‐General must increase the risk of corruption.

Indeed, the Herald‐Sun has expressed concern about these terms of reference which would potentially allow government agencies to appoint their own auditors and bypass the Victorian Auditor‐General's office, thereby seriously eroding his power to vet government actions. The Herald‐Sun went on to say that the recent revelations that two of the three members of the government appointed review panel have been associated with companies involved in matters which previously drew serious criticism from the Victorian Auditor‐General is of some concern. And well it might be because what we, in fact, have is that two of the three people are Mr Ken Spencer, a director of Crown Casino and a key Citylink company. Back in May, a report by Mr Baragwanath found that the government had undercharged Crown Casino $174 million in tax for 150 extra gaming tables—a very serious and scathing report.

Indeed, the Auditor‐General had also commented adversely on the Sandridge City Development Company, of which one of the directors was Mr John Dahlsen, a second person appointed to review the Office of the Victorian Auditor‐General. So you have two of the people conducting this review into the Office of the Victorian Auditor‐General having been in the past subject of adverse reports by the Victorian Auditor‐General.

The Victorian Premier once again shows himself to be, on occasion, a person of some ability but utterly corrupt. Like rotten mackerel at moonlight, he shines and stinks. It is appalling that we have directors of companies that have been reported on adversely by the Auditor‐General now being required to investigate whether the Auditor‐General in Victoria can be bypassed by allowing government departments to appoint their own auditors.

Let me take the committee back to the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which make it clear that the Auditor‐General ought to be able to determine his own program of work. It says:
It is a generally held principle that an auditee should not appoint the auditor because in so doing the independence or perceived independence of the auditor can be compromised.
That is exactly right. The joint committee went on to make recommendations to enshrine this principle in legislation, a principle which I strongly support. Recommendation 14 says:
The Auditor‐General Bill should provide that:
(a) the Auditor‐General is to be appointed as the auditor of all Commonwealth entities; and
(b) the Auditor‐General has a general mandate to initiate the full range of audits in relation to all Commonwealth entities (including performance audits of Government Business Enterprises).

In so doing, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has repudiated the proposals of the Victorian Premier which would undermine the independence of the Victorian Auditor‐General. It has made it clear that the Auditor‐General should be appointed with the involvement of the parliament through the Joint Committee of Public Accounts recommissioned as an audit committee of the parliament, and that that Auditor‐General would be able to set his or her own program of investigations and not have this situation, spuriously justified by reference to competition policy, whereby the Auditor-General might be, effectively, bypassed, with government departments being able to determine their own audit arrangements.

In the past, private sector auditors, as others have noted, have not been able to determine failures in advance. They have only been able to determine these things after the event. As a result, many bodies have decided that the Kennett government's decision to review the scope of the state Auditor‐General's powers is unwelcome. The National Competition Council said that this was not a priority of the national competition agreement. We have had the Victorian Council for Civil Liberties, the Institute of Chartered Accountants and even the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly all saying that they do not think that this is the right way to go.

We had the former Chairman of the Victorian Public Accounts and Estimates Committee—and, indeed, I served on that Public Accounts and Estimates Committee under Mr Weideman— indicating that the government should not be holding this kind of review. A number of Liberal backbenchers, lacking the courage, let me say, to have themselves named, off the record indicated that they are outraged by this proposal. And well they might be because, if we look at the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, aptly named Guarding the independence of the Auditor‐General, this has to be a priority for any parliament, be it the Commonwealth parliament, the Victorian parliament, or the parliaments of other states and territories.

I am pleased to see that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is coming up with recommendations that give effect to that most important concept, the independence of the Auditor‐General, and seeking to safeguard that through a variety of recommendations. But I am most disturbed that, while the Commonwealth is making these sorts of appropriate moves, in Victoria we have the Auditor‐General being scuttled for daring to criticise, as he has done on occasion, measures of the Victorian government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of brief comments on Report 346 , as a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in the 37th parliament and again in the 38th parliament, and having been also a participant in this inquiry and the previous inquiry into the role of the Auditor‐General in the Commonwealth. I note with interest the comments of the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) with regard to Victoria. At some stages in the processes and activities of the office of the Auditor‐General under the previous incumbent of that position—not the current incumbent—there were times when the relationship between the former Auditor‐General and the former government of the Commonwealth of Australia was strained. It is in that regard that we were attempting to identify some key areas where there should be no dissent as far as the activities of the Auditor‐General are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: The very first recommendation in this report highlights the importance of the perception as well as, nominally, the independence of the Auditor‐General as being not an advocate of the executive, not an advocate of government, but a person who is working on behalf of the parliament of Australia and therefore, by extension, the people of Australia in so far as his or her review of what activities of the Commonwealth are being undertaken. Recommendation No. 1 is one of the key recommendations in this report.

Those of us in this parliament that work in close proximity to the Commonwealth departments know that the Auditor‐General is independent. We felt it important that that position be nominally declared that way so that it gives much more succour to the people of Australia that they have a watchdog watching not only what government is doing but also what the bureaucracy is doing. It is very important in that regard that this recommendation be accepted, and we look forward with anticipation to the government's response to this report and recommendations.
The other recommendation I want to comment on, and which the previous speaker did allude to, is also very important. That is recommendation No. 14, which states:
The Auditor‐General Bill should provide that:
(a) the Auditor‐General is to be appointed as the auditor of all Commonwealth entities; and
(b) the Auditor‐General has a general mandate to initiate the full range of audits in relation to all Commonwealth entities (including performance audits of Government Business Enterprises).

Government business enterprises are government businesses. The government is the sole shareholder in those business enterprises. Again, by extension, they are owned by the taxpayers of Australia. There is a reasonable expectation by the taxpayers of Australia that their auditor—their independent auditor, the defender of the interests of the people of Australia in these organisations—should have the ability to access and perform not financial audits, where it is just tick, tick, tick, but performance audits. Then the shareholders of those government business enterprises, the taxpayers of Australia, can be assured that those businesses are being managed productively and efficiently on their behalf and that it is being done in quite a prudent way.
I thank the Main Committee for its indulgence in allowing me to make a few remarks on that, and I commend the report to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on this report. Firstly, I want to congratulate Alex Somlyay and the committee. This is a very important report.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that you start having an even greater interest in the role of the parliament once you shift from the government to the opposition benches. Those power imbalances that you found discomforting in government become alarming in opposition. But seriously, as members of parliament we all have a responsibility as we go toward the year 2000 to make this institution stronger and more effective. That is not altogether easy, particularly in our House, which is the House of the executive, the House that the executive dominates.

The role of committees is fundamentally important. I am not trying to score some cheap points, but the truth of the matter is that the committees, which I have described as the universities of parliament, have been curtailed significantly by financial cutbacks. People want to run the argument with me that, yes, they are still doing good work, et cetera. I think that is true too, and I guess this report is in part a reflection of it. But once you cut the financial resources of committees without trying to rebalance and get some intellectual horsepower into it, you are diminishing the role of the backbenchers on both sides of parliament.

An important aspect of the role of parliamentarians is having input from independent officers of the parliament, and this is where my particular compliments go to the Public Accounts Committee because it has looked at the independent role of the Auditor‐General. I have been very interested in the Ombudsman, who is in a similar position—that is, she is not a member of the executive, her role is seen as being independent, but it also needs guarding. In fact, it was my privilege to introduce a private member's bill which sought to strengthen the role of the Commonwealth Ombudsman vis‐a‐vis the rest of the executive. I must say I wish I had had this report available, or benefit of the discussions that led to the report, prior to the private member's bill, because I certainly would have picked up some of the initiatives in it.

One of the particular initiatives is that there should be an audit committee. If I have one quibble with the recommendations, it is that it suggests that the audit committee is going to approve the budget for the Auditor‐General. Theoretically, I must say I am very attracted to that proposition, but I think the reality will fall short and we will not get governments of the day to agree to it. But having an audit committee gives the Auditor‐General a great deal of opportunity, particularly given the new method of appointment and the hearings that are proposed. In fact, what the audit committee really becomes is the champion, if you like, of the Auditor‐General in terms of the function that he performs.

One of the pleasing innovations I introduced as chairman of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee was for the first time to actually have the Human Rights Commissioner come before the human rights subcommittee. It had not been done before. I am pleased that in this parliament we have actually seen the Ombudsman, who I think also fulfils a very important human rights role in Australia, come before the human rights subcommittee.

The Auditor‐General has enjoyed, over the time I have been in this place, an excellent relationship with the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, and the committee is to be commended for that. Mind you, it mostly deals with his work, that is, all the audit reports that are presented.

What I am trying to say, I guess, is that we not only need to try to provide some legislative protection for these independent officers of the parliament—the Ombudsman and the Auditor‐General—but equally it is the informal links that can be of critical importance. When the Auditor‐General knows he has the confidence of the audit committee, he can bring issues of concern to the audit committee. We, in turn, as members of parliament hold that committee responsible for sifting through those concerns and bringing to our notice anything worthy of our attention and placing it on the public record, so that, whether you are in opposition or you are a government backbencher or a senator, it is on the record. If more people outside the place want to take note of what has been placed on the public record, that is even more to the good.

I have commented on the issue of resourcing, which is a very difficult issue. What happens at the moment is that the Auditor‐General is an outrider of Finance, the Ombudsman is an outrider of PM&C, and what you tend to find with outrider organisations is that they take a deeper cut than the department itself. It is so much easier for the department head to justify why his own specific portfolio responsibilities need to be maintained, or be less cut into than some of the other organisations. Indeed, that is what has happened in this budget. And in relation to the Ombudsman, I think that will have tragic consequences for ordinary Australians in their ability to have access to a level of justice with regard to complaints about the Public Service.

It is true that a 1994‐95 report of the Auditor‐General is yet to be adequately responded to in allowing her to follow the money trail, because so much these days is outsourced from departments to other providers. It is no good just holding the department accountable because they can always say, `We are not fulfilling this function.' There needs to be a healthy debate about that. But, at the end of the day, I think all members of parliament will want to say, `If it is a Commonwealth function, irrespective of how or who is performing it, we want to follow the dollar trail.' It may come as a surprise to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it is not the individual citizens who tend to be the worst victims of this, it is actually small business. They are the victims and the Ombudsman cannot deal with it. So resources is a big issue.

If we are saying that the audit committee will approve the budget, I wish you luck. We cannot even insulate this parliament. The Senate's role and responsibility, in opposition, is something I am now recasting in my own mind's eye. But even the Senate, as powerful as it is, cannot protect itself from cutbacks—much less the House. It is a terrible admission we make as members of parliament. If there are more effective and efficient ways of doing things, of course we are open to it and would respond to it, but we cannot protect ourselves from cutbacks.

For example, I would argue passionately that there are a couple of things we need to do with committees. We need to get some young university graduates, perhaps honours graduates, in there on a 12‐ to 18‐month basis and put them on a special contract. Maybe we could have one, two or three. It would give the committees some real horsepower, give these people some experience and really make the committees more effective. It would be a very cost‐effective way of spending the dollar. We cannot pretend to the Australian people that committees are going to be as effective as we would like them to be when we keep on tightening the purse strings. The demands on committees for reports, investigations and studies are increasing, not diminishing. I know people like to say you can do more with less—and maybe you can initially—but there comes a point where you cannot.

We all have a stake in the institution of parliament and parliamentarians being seen to be more responsive to the Australian people. We try to do that in our electorates. But the way we do it as an institution is through our committee work and through the important work being done by people such as the Auditor‐General, the Ombudsman and perhaps also the human rights commissioners. That is why they deserve special attention, special merit and special concern by all members of parliament.
I guess my time is running out. In summary, I congratulate Alex Somlyay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Congratulate the member for Fairfax, too.

—I am sorry; I congratulate the member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) and all the members of the committee. I am conscious that everyone contributes to committee reports. I congratulate them on their report. The report, modestly entitled Report 346 , is an exceptionally important report. For people who are not on the committee, I would have to say that government members—more than opposition members—have a responsibility to make sure that this report is not merely tabled, thrown away or the subject of various discussions and nothing else.

SPEECH.PARA: What you do for the Auditor‐General is going to have ramifications for the Ombudsman. Already the Senate is looking at my private member's bill in relation to the Ombudsman. Without any disrespect to the Senate committee, I would invite them to look at this report, because I see my feeble attempts to strengthen her role and function and to provide some safeguards, which the Auditor‐General is proposed to have in this report, would really sit well with her.

The Ombudsman has never had a relationship with a committee as the Auditor‐General has with the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and it has left her vulnerable. I think it is a most important function. I ask the committee not to be disappointed if every recommendation that has been made is not implemented. I think there is much that we should resist not being implemented. In the year 2000, all institutions have to re‐evaluate themselves. In this parliament, we want to become more relevant and more meaningful to people. The most effective way we can do it as members of parliament is to look at the institution and the institutions it services, and particularly the committees. I commend the report.
Debate (on motion by Mr Neville) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 September, on motion by Mr Vaile:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, before commencing my remarks, I thank you and the two whips for allowing me to complete the debate on this particular issue, even though we will go slightly over time. I respect your generosity and I will keep my comments as brief as possible. We are reporting on Keeping rural Australia posted—an inquiry into Australia Post: rural and remote letter delivery services .

SPEECH.PARA: I was on this committee, both in the 37th and 38th parliaments, on this particular issue, and there were three terms of reference common to both parliaments. They were the need for and the extent of Australia Post's community service obligation; the cost and funding of those community service obligations, given the size of Australia Post's commercial obligations; and the capacity of Australia Post to maintain current performance standards and options for increasing those performance standards under section 28C of the Australia Postal Corporation Act 1989 in those communities. There was a fourth term of reference in the 37th parliament, which the committee touched on later.

For people in remote and rural Australia, the postal service is a vital part of communications. I come from one such area and it is a common theme wherever I move in my electorate and, indeed, outside my electorate, when people knew that I was on this inquiry, to raise this matter of postal services and communications in general. We have seen in the parliament in the last week just how ferociously Australians guard their access to communications—indeed, even to the point of the way they are delivered and the visual efficacy of how they are delivered. But for people in country areas, that luxury is not always available. A basic service is what they sometimes have to settle for. As the whole face of communications changes, with interactive cable services, e‐mail, faxes, modems, telephone cost reductions and the Internet, there is great anxiety in rural areas about where postal services might end up.

The postal service is still arguably the most important communications service for country and rural people—certainly the most important after a basic telephone service. It is interesting to note by way of background just where Australia Post stands in the world. The cost of sending a letter in Australia is, as you know, 45c. In New Zealand it is 42c; in Canada and the US, 44c—I am quoting the costs in Australian currency—going right up to 99c in Germany and $1.31 in Japan. So Australia Post has much to commend it in being able to give such a good service to a very diverse nation over a large area for 45c.

It is also interesting to note the value of privatisation and the move towards corporatisation in many government agencies, although I am not suggesting for a moment that we should go beyond corporatisation of Australia Post. It is interesting to note that the profit in millions of dollars for Australia Post is $249 million a year, compared with $39 million in Canada, a negative figure of $1.7 billion in the US, about $560 million in the UK and about $101 million in New Zealand.

It is also interesting to note that, of the postal authorities in the nations I have mentioned, only the ones in Australia, the UK and New Zealand pay tax. Interestingly again, they would appear to be the ones that have the best return on assets, at 25 per cent in New Zealand, 12½ per cent in Australia and seven per cent in Great Britain, whereas Canada and the US have very low figures, if not negative figures.

I do not want my comments to be interpreted as an attack on Australia Post; they are not. But there is, as I said, a very real concern about the community service obligation. As the terms of reference state, this inquiry is focused primarily on an examination of Australia Post's community service obligation; that is, an obligation when a government specifically requires a public enterprise to carry out activities relating to outputs or inputs which it would not elect to do on a commercial basis.

BREAK.PARA: At present, Australia Post is required by law to deliver the standard letter within Australia at a standard rate of 45c, regardless of the costs incurred. The findings of the committee were in support of maintaining this standard rate. Furthermore, we believed that that should be by cross‐subsidisation.

We received 249 submissions to the inquiry and 11 exhibits. Out of that, we then took evidence from a wide cross‐section of government, private industry and the various government agencies. Out of that came 20 specific recommendations, and one general recommendation for an ongoing investigation into Australia Post's reserve services.
The main thing we recommended was that there be another:
. . . polling exercise of the 80,000 people who do not have a `to the property' delivery.
If those communities vote for a `to the property' service, we believe that that should be delivered.
We recommended that the `to the property' delivery be based on recommendation 1, the one I have just quoted, and that:
. . . Australia Post first give priority to households with students studying by distance education or with people requiring a regular supply of medicines.
You must remember that in many regional and remote areas there are no pharmacies and that is a very important part of the service.

We also recommended that 51 Aboriginal communities, greater than 50 km from Australia Post retail facilities, be given Australia Post retail facilities and that we look at, generally, Australia Post services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and their general access to postal services.
However, my main concern was with four of these recommendations. One was:

Australia Post upgrade Licensed Post Offices or Community Postal Agencies to include banking services in cases where the standard banking service in a rural or remote community are closed. If necessary, the cost of this service should be included in the community service obligation . . .

As you well know, a lot of banks have withdrawn from rural areas and this is a very important aspect of rural life. A lot of government services have been withdrawn over the last decade, both state and federal, and with banks going that has left many communities devoid of any sort of service. Australia Post is developing such a banking service and we have recommended that that should be part of the community service obligation.

What is also not generally recognised is that there are three levels of post office: the corporate post offices which are still run by Australia Post itself; licensed post offices which are somewhat of a franchise, if you like, run by individuals on a profit basis; and community postal agencies which are sometimes in a hardware store, or a general store, or something like that, in a country town. My general view is that these have not been given much of a go, especially the lower tier—the community postal agency—and that point was made very clear during the inquiry.

There are two ways you can deliver a community service obligation: one is to have a line in your budget, the other is to cross-subsidise. We believe, in a bipartisan way, that it is absolutely essential that the cross-subsidy provision be maintained. We believe that the budget line is subject to tampering by future governments and should not be tolerated. The government also is asked to:
. . . give an undertaking to rural and remote Australia that it will not use budgetary payments as a means of paying for Australia Post's Community Service Obligations.

We have asked that heritage buildings, which are also a very important part of provincial Australia and some parts of rural Australia, be maintained and that provision be made on the books of Australia Post to recognise that.

It was a very wide ranging inquiry with quite a lot of submissions and witnesses, and there were those 20 recommendations. Looking to the future, we have recommended in a general way that the government, by way of inquiry, looking for revenue generated by reserve services, look at the comparative efficiencies of reserve services and non-reserve services. It should look at the question of reducing the reserve services to three, two or one times the standard letter rate, and the implications for Australia Post operations as a result of the potential growth in indirect competition from telephone, facsimile and electronic mail, which I referred to earlier in my address.
I thank you for your indulgence and I commend the report to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Grace) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 25 June 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: For each Job Club project conducted in the Minister's Department's Melbourne East area what was the (a) total funding provided, (b) total number of commencements, (c) unit cost and (d) total number of outcomes (i) in 1990‐91, (ii) in 1991‐92, (iii) in 1992‐93, (iv) in 1993‐94 (v) in 1994‐95 and (vi) between 1 July 1995 and 25 June 1996.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The geographical area covered by the Department's Area Melbourne East has changed three times since 1 July 1990. The current Regional Office configuration has, however, been in place since 1992‐93 and reliable data can only be provided from that financial year onwards.

The attached table describes Area Melbourne East Job Clubs contracts, by the financial year in which they were signed. Against each contract is the total level of funding received, the total number of commencements registered and the consequent unit cost.

Up until the end of 1994, Job Club contracts were awarded on a calendar year rather than a financial year basis. Accordingly, Job Clubs are listed by the financial year in which they were contracted. However, a proportion (which cannot be quantified) of the contracts' expenditure and commencements contracted in one year may actually take place in the following financial year.

The "total outcomes" data provided are those known as positive outcomes, i.e. those former Job Club participants who found employment or chose to undertake non‐Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs funded education or training, and which were identified through the Department's Post Program Monitoring (PPM) survey. Not all former LMP participants return their PPM survey forms and, therefore, any outcome figures quoted will not relate strictly to all former clients who have participated in an LMP. The percentage of Job Club positive outcomes in the attached tables can only be reliably stated at Area level because the proportion of known client outcomes at the provider level is often too low to be statistically robust.
AREA MELBOURNE EAST JOB CLUBS PROJECTS SINCE 1992‐93

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the impact on income tax collections of fiscal drag/bracket creep in the 1996 Budget.
(2) What plans does the Government have for the introduction of tax indexation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no estimate of fiscal drag in the Budget Statements, 1996‐97. However, as inflation is low, and expected to remain low, fiscal drag for 1996‐97 and the forward estimates period would have a much lower impact than was the case when inflation was relatively high under the previous government.
(2) The Government has no plans for the introduction of tax indexation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the net public sector borrowing requirement shown any trend increase since 1976.
(2) Has net public debt shown any trend increase since 1976.
(3) Has the gap between private investment and private saving in Australia widened since 1976.
(4) How has the inflation‐adjusted, cyclically corrected public sector balance in Australia altered since 1971.
(5) How do Australia's public sector deficits and public debt compare to other member nations of the OECD.
(6) What evidence is there to support his assertion that Australia has an inter‐generational public sector budgetary problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The net public sector borrowing requirement has fluctuated significantly over the past two decades, so the trend figures are not meaningful. As the Commonwealth public sector borrowing requirement includes the effect of asset sales and repayment of State debt it has not been a useful indicator of the impact of the public sector on national savings in recent years.

(2) There has been a clear trend increase in Commonwealth General Government debt, the component which arises mainly from Commonwealth Budget deficit. This is now the largest component of public sector debt.

(3) In the past 30 years private sector net lending (private saving less private investment) has fluctuated widely over the course of the business cycle. As shown in Chart 17 of Statement 2 of 1996-97 Budget Paper No. 1, there have been periods of both significant net lending and net borrowing. After allowing for cyclical sensitivities, private investment has remained a fairly constant proportion of GDP. Private saving also remained reasonably steady as a proportion of GDP up to the early 1980s but since then has shown a gradual trend decline. This has been more than accounted for by a decline in household saving, offset partly by an increase in corporate saving, including private financial enterprise saving.
(4) No public sector balance data are currently available on an inflation‐adjusted, cyclically corrected basis.

(5) The OECD Economic Outlook provides data on financial balances and net financial liabilities for the total general government sector for selected OECD member countries. While the OECD does adjust data in an attempt to improve comparability between countries, there remains the need to exercise caution in making cross‐country comparisons, as methods of data collection, coverage and classification can differ between countries.

In the early 1990s the general government deficit in Australia exceeded the OECD average over a few years. Despite growth in the economy since then, Australia's fiscal position remained in deficit at 2½ per cent of GDP in 1995. Labor left Australia with the highest current account deficit in the OECD, and this imbalance between national savings and investment must be addressed by boosting national savings. Commonwealth budget deficits in recent years have been a major source of the poor national savings performance.

In regard to Australia's levels of gross and net debt, it is the pace at which net debt levels have built up in recent years—particularly in the Commonwealth general government sector—that has required corrective action. A series of large budget deficits over recent years has resulted in Commonwealth general government net debt rising from around 4 per cent of GDP in 1989‐90 to over 19 per cent of GDP in 1995-96. Without corrective action Commonwealth general government net debt would remain broadly unchanged as a proportion of GDP, with a high probability of ratcheting up further in the future.

(6) The Commonwealth general government sector has generally been in deficit in underlying terms over the past two decades reflecting a generally significant dissaving position. A dissaving position by the Commonwealth general government sector means that it is reducing the level of public sector net worth and therefore potentially disadvantaging future generations.

(2) How many Medicare offices are there in each electoral division in Queensland.
(3) What is the average population size served by each Queensland Medicare office.
(4) What are the smallest centres serviced by Queensland Medicare offices and what is the population size of those centres.
(5) What proportion of Medicare services were direct billed between 1 June 1995 and 31 May 1996 in the electoral division of Fisher.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

ANSWER.PARA: (1) This information is detailed at attachment A.
There are no Medicare offices located in the electorates of Longman or Moreton.
(3) The average population size for metropolitan areas serviced by Queensland Medicare offices is approximately 99,000. There are 17 metropolitan offices.
The average population size for country areas serviced by Queensland Medicare offices is approximately 97,000. There are 33 country offices.
(The population figures have been derived from the 1991 Census data.)
(4) Country
Figures have been derived from the 1991 Census data.

(5) Data for the specific period 1 June 1995 to 31 May 1996 was unavailable at the time of preparing this response. For the period 1 July 1995 to 30 June 1996, 82.4% of total Medicare services were direct billed in the electoral division of Fisher (total services 30,801, direct bill services 25,379).

(2) Has the federal Government allocated funding under the Blackspot program for 1997; if so, was a sum allocated for traffic lights at the intersection of Benara Road and Lord Street, Beechboro, WA; if not, when will funding be allocated and announced.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No, the WA Government has not submitted projects for funding under the Black Spot Program in 1997.
(2) Yes, the federal Government has allocated funding under the Black Spot Program for 1997.

The Minister for Transport and Regional Development wrote to the WA Minister for Transport, the Hon Eric Charlton MLC, on 15 October 1996 inviting participation in the Program and advising that the following notional allocation of funds had been made available to WA:
As no submission of projects for funding has been received at this stage, no allocation of funds to individual projects has been made.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Hydropower in Laos: Australian Government Involvement

PARA.TAB: Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 November 1996:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1) What is the extent of the Australian Government's involvement, under the UN Development Program (UNDP), in facilitating hydropower expansion in Laos.
(2) Are there three AusAID‐funded positions within the Hydropower Project Office of the Laotian Ministry for Industry and Handicraft; if so, what are the job descriptions for the positions.
(3) What were the findings of the AusAID Cost Engineer at the Ministry for Industry and Handicraft.
(4) Is the Cost Engineer's report publicly available; if not, is this contrary to AusAID's commitment to openness in its operations.
(5) Will the position of Cost Engineer be filled again.
(6) What mechanisms exist for personnel to report to AusAID and UNDP.

(7) Does AusAID maintain working relationships with Australian companies operating in Laos, including Transfield and Tasmanian Hydroelectric Commission Enterprises Corporation; if so, what are the details.
(8) What is the total cost of the Laotian hydropower project and what is AusAID's contribution.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: — the answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Lao government has identified hydropower as its primary resource to provide revenue to develop the country. The Hydropower Project Office (HPO) has the responsibility of assessing commercial proposals to develop hydropower in Laos. Given Laos' status as a "least developed country" the HPO lacks education, skills and experience to properly assess the hydropower proposals to ensure that the people of Laos receive a fair return from the utilisation of a major national resource, and that all environmental, social, legal and technical concerns are met. The United Nations Development Program (UNDP) approached AusAID and sought Australian participation in an assistance program aimed at upgrading the skills levels of HPO personnel and at establishing a system that will allow hydropower proposals to be properly assessed.

Specifically Australian assistance is in two parts. Firstly, AusAID is funding, through UNDP, a full time "Power Development Adviser" at the HPO. Secondly, AusAID is directly funding a number of short term advisers and training programs for HPO staff.

(2) There is only one full time AusAID funded position at the HPO, the "Power Development Adviser". This Long Term Adviser assists the HPO to plan and manage the appropriate development of hydropower in Laos, taking account of all relevant environmental, social, legal and technical factors. The Long Term Adviser has four specific functions: to advise the HPO on the planning of power sector development for Laos; to advise the HPO on the financing options and ownership arrangements for power schemes; to advise the HPO on the further development of individual power schemes; and to identify specific HPO needs for short term specialist assistance and training in legal, financial, and technical fields, and assist in the identification and selection of expert sources of this specialist assistance and training.
AusAID‐funded short term advisers include a financial adviser, a costing engineer, an environment adviser and a legal adviser, with assignments of between one and two months.

(3) The Cost Engineer's assignment was to develop a common format for the presentation of costing information by the proponents of commercial hydropower schemes, and to establish a computerised data base and train HPO personnel in its use. The assignment was successfully completed. There were no "findings" as such.
(4) Yes. The report is available.
(5) No. The Cost Engineer had a specific assignment which has been completed.

(6) The full time Power Development Adviser is contracted to the UNDP and he reports to them. AusAID receives copies of his reports. The short term advisers provide a report to AusAID on their activities at the completion of their assignments. AusAID personnel in Vientiane monitor the project and have regular contact with the advisers.

(7) AusAID maintains close working relationships with companies implementing Australian aid projects in Laos. This included Transfield Constructions which was contracted, through a tender process, to be the construction manager of a project to build 4 bridges in a remote area in north‐eastern Laos. The Tasmanian Hydroelectric Commission Enterprises Corporation does not implement any AusAID projects in Laos.
(8) The project is ongoing and the final cost has yet to be determined. The total cost of the AusAID contribution to the project is estimated to be $1.0 million.
